explainability.path_to_improvement: Document how explanations are provided to users affected by AI decisions.

external_accountability.path_to_improvement: Obtain external validation of AI practices or require vendor certifications.

fairness.path_to_improvement: Document bias testing procedures or vendor AI fairness requirements.

governance.findings: An SEC filing acknowledges artificial intelligence as a material business risk and indicates the company's recognition of the need to manage AI's benefits and risks. Sustainability reports detail the strategy of using AI technology for environmental monitoring and customer feedback, and mention managing risks associated with AI.

relevant_sources.summary: This SEC Form 10-K filing explicitly acknowledges artificial intelligence as a material business risk, supporting the **governance** pillar by indicating the company's recognition of the need to manage AI's benefits and risks. The filing also provides evidence for the **oversight** pillar by mentioning the board's role in AI adoption and governance, along with annual training and reviews, suggesting active management and operational execution of AI-related strategies.
relevant_sources.title: SEC Form 10-K FY 2024 - Technology and Information Security Risks

relevant_sources.summary: The WM 2023 Sustainability Report provides evidence for the **governance** pillar of responsible AI. The report details WM's strategy of using AI technology to track contamination patterns in recyclables, supported by onboard truck computers. This indicates a governance framework for the implementation and utilization of AI for environmental monitoring and customer feedback, aiming to improve recycling quality.
relevant_sources.title: WM 2023 Sustainability Report - Smart Truck Contamination Tracking

relevant_sources.summary: The "WM 2024 Sustainability Report - Digital Tool and Automation" provides evidence for the **governance** pillar. This company-owned report mentions managing risks associated with AI, indicating a focus on governance by acknowledging potential issues, even if it's a policy statement rather than a description of operational execution.
relevant_sources.title: WM 2024 Sustainability Report - Digital Tool and Automation

oversight.findings: An SEC filing mentions the board's role in AI adoption and governance. This filing also references annual training and reviews related to AI.

relevant_sources.summary: This SEC Form 10-K filing explicitly acknowledges artificial intelligence as a material business risk, supporting the **governance** pillar by indicating the company's recognition of the need to manage AI's benefits and risks. The filing also provides evidence for the **oversight** pillar by mentioning the board's role in AI adoption and governance, along with annual training and reviews, suggesting active management and operational execution of AI-related strategies.
relevant_sources.title: SEC Form 10-K FY 2024 - Technology and Information Security Risks

privacy.path_to_improvement: Document data protection practices for AI systems, including vendor AI data handling.

transparency.findings: A company blog post describes the deployment of AI in Smart Technology Recycling Trucks. This post explains that AI is used for analysis to identify recycling challenges and boost efficiency.
transparency.path_to_improvement: Document AI systems in use, including vendor/third-party AI tools.

relevant_sources.summary: This company-owned blog post provides evidence for the **transparency** pillar by describing the use of AI in WM's Smart Technology Recycling Trucks. The blog post explains that AI is used for analysis to identify recycling challenges and boost efficiency, indicating a degree of transparency about the AI's deployment and its general purpose.
relevant_sources.title: WM Smart Technology Recycling Trucks - Blog Post

summary.overall_findings: Waste Management's public disclosures indicate that an SEC filing mentions the board's role in AI adoption and governance, addressing the oversight pillar. This is one of two responsible AI pillars with documented evidence out of seven evaluated, with governance materials acknowledging artificial intelligence as a material business risk and recognizing the need to manage AI's benefits and risks. Drawing from 7 publicly available sources, the assessment found no qualifying public evidence for the majority of the 7 evaluated pillars.
